fields.description:
Currently users are able to filter by project but not by board. 

Use case:

Issues can only be assigned to one team. For some issue types like Actions, I need several teams on board. 

Note: some teams use lower levels of hierarchy but some will only follow their actions and won't need nor use any other issue type.
fields.summary: Possibility to filter plan by board

fields.description:
h2. Problem Definition

It is not possible to create a Pie Chart that shows the distribution of tickets per Jira Portfolio custom field Team, as the Team custom field is not available in

* the statistics type drop down list for the Pie Chart gadget
 !PS28243_PieChart.png|thumbnail! 

* the X or Y axix for the Two Dimensional gadget
 !PS28243_2DimGadget.png|thumbnail! 



 
h2. Suggested Solution

It will be very useful to be able to use the Jira Portfolio Team custom field in the Jira Pie Chart gadget as well as the Two Dimensional gadget.  

Please allow the Team custom field to be available for both gadgets.
fields.summary: Make the Jira Portfolio Team custom field available for Jira gadgets

fields.description:
It would be nice if Portfolio supported non-standard custom field types provided by custom plugins.

 

One example for which our clients really need it is nFeed. It works really well with Issue Navigator, Dashboard, even the REST API, but Portfolio refuses to even try displaying it.
fields.summary: Show non-standard custom field types in scope views

fields.description:
It should be possible to easily create a portfolio-child ticket starting from the ticket view (e.g menu item in "more") which follows the portfolio-child relation and is properly linked.

E.g. if I'm in a Portfolio level epic I can create a Program level child which is properly linked to the Portfolio Epic I started from (parent link). Ideally, I have similar options as cloning a ticket i.e. copying attributes across like version, description, reporter,... etc to minimize the effort of creating the child. This also requires that I can chose between different ticket types at the portfolio levels we defined and also chose the JIRA project this ticket should be created in.
fields.summary: Portfolio linking

fields.description:
h3. How to Replicate
 # Create a project in Jira.
 # Create a plan in Portfolio.
 # Navigate to *Reports > Share > Embed* and copy the HTML code.
 # Paste the HTML code inside an HTML file, like in the example below:
{code:none|bgColor=#f8f8f8}
<!doctype html>
<html>
<body>
	<iframe src='http://your-jira-instance/secure/PortfolioSharedReportView.jspa?r=PIKKY&t&e' width='1024' height='640' style='border : 1px solid #ccc;'></iframe></body>
</html>	
{code}

 # Open this HTML file using an *incognito* window in the browser.
 # Open *developer tools* in this browser window.
 # The content inside the iframe will be rendered as below:
 !authentication-attempts.png|thumbnail!
 # Notice how there will be one HTTP request to {{/rest/jpo/1.0/authentication/test}} every second.

h3. Instance Details

Reproduced on Jira 7.2.12 and Portfolio 2.6.1 and 2.14.1
fields.summary: Plan report page in iframe floods Jira with auth requests when accessed by unauthed user

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, if a Portfolio plan is set to show issues in all status, Portfolio will show *Statuses: All*. But when a user clicked the status drop-down menu, Portfolio does not tick any of the statuses. 

This could cause some users to interpreted it as Portfolio not configured to show issues from all the statuses.


h3. Suggested Solution

Make Portfolio to tick all the statuses from the plan when a user clicked on the status dropdown & the plan is configured to display issues from all the statuses.


h3. Workaround 

None. Even though none of the statuses is ticked, Portfolio will show issues in all the statuses if the "Statuses" menu is shown as *Statuses: All*.
fields.summary: Improve Status Dropdown Menu

fields.description:
*Steps to recreate:*

* Add two users as editors  to a Portfolio program
* remove one user from the program
* login in as a JIRA admin
* delete the user that is the only editor on the Program

*Expected results:*
Portfolio should use a default group and specific users 

*Actual Results:*
Portfolio Program is inaccessible to all users and groups 

*Workaround:*
(!) Please ensure to backup the database before attempting any of the below instructions.  If a problem occurs, restoring the database may be necessary.

Update the AO_D9132D_PERMISSIONS table to reflect an active user's app_user key:


1. As you can see portuser is still tied to the program even though I just deleted that user:
{code:sql}
  mysql> select * from AO_D9132D_PERMISSIONS;
+------------+-------------+----+------------+---------+------------+
| HOLDER_KEY | HOLDER_TYPE | ID | PERMISSION | PLAN_ID | PROGRAM_ID |
+------------+-------------+----+------------+---------+------------+
| portuser   |           0 | 12 |          1 |    NULL |          1 |
+------------+-------------+----+------------+---------+------------+
1 row in set (0.00 sec)
{code}

2. Let's look at my users in app_user:
{code:sql}
mysql> select * from app_user
    -> ;
+-------+----------+-----------------+
| ID    | user_key | lower_user_name |
+-------+----------+-----------------+
| 10000 | ronnie   | ronnie          |
| 10100 | test     | ronaldo         |
| 10101 | ronniev  | ronniev         |
| 10102 | tester   | tester123       |
| 10103 | portuser | portuser        |
+-------+----------+-----------------+
5 rows in set (0.00 sec)
{code}

ronnie is a good user 

3. update  AO_D9132D_PERMISSIONS to reflect the user_key of an accessible user:
{code:sql}
update AO_D9132D_PERMISSIONS set HOLDER_KEY='ronnie' where id=12;
{code}
(!)Make sure that you use the data from your db. i.e. HOLDER_KEY and id from AO_D9132D_PERMISSIONS
Now we have an accessible program:
{code:sql}
mysql> select * from AO_D9132D_PERMISSIONS;
+------------+-------------+----+------------+---------+------------+
| HOLDER_KEY | HOLDER_TYPE | ID | PERMISSION | PLAN_ID | PROGRAM_ID |
+------------+-------------+----+------------+---------+------------+
| ronnie     |           0 | 12 |          1 |    NULL |          1 |
+------------+-------------+----+------------+---------+------------+
1 row in set (0.00 sec)
{code}
fields.summary: deleting editor user tied to programs leaves program inaccessible

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When navigating between tabs in a Portfolio Plan or refreshing the page, custom date time fields that had been unchecked re-appear in the Scope. 
h3. Environment

Portfolio versions 2.13.3 and 2.14.0
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Add a custom field with type “Date Picker” or “Date Time Picker” to a Portfolio Plan.
 # Click the Scope options (gear icon) and uncheck the custom field that contains a date or date/time value.
 # Navigate from Scope to Teams and back again, or simply refresh the page.

h3. Expected Results

The custom field that was unchecked should no longer be visible.
h3. Actual Results

The custom field that was unchecked has re-appeared.
h3. Workaround

There is no known workaround.
fields.summary: Unable to toggle custom date fields in Portfolio

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When a user selects the Scope tab while in Program View, he/she will notice two *Scheduled end* columns instead of the normal *Scheduled start & Scheduled end* visualization. 

h3. Environment
* Jira Software 7.10.0 & 7.10.1
* Portfolio for Jira 2.14.0 & 2.14.1

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Select *Portfolio > Create...*
# Select *Program (group of plans)*
# Insert a program's name
# Select the plans the program will connect to
# Hit *Create*
# Select *Scope*

h3. Expected Results
Under the Scope tab there should be a *Scheduled start & Scheduled end* columns.

h3. Actual Results
Two *Scheduled end* columns are displayed. See screen shot.
 

h3.Workaround
None at the moment.
fields.summary: Program View showing two 'Scheduled end' columns

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Searching for "Parent Link is EMPTY" or "Parent Link is not EMPTY" in issue navigator is not giving out correct results.


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create issue A of type Initiative
# Create issue B of type Epic with Parent Link = issue A
# Search for the JQL: {{key = issueB_Key AND "Parent Link" is not EMPTY}} >>> we get 1 result, issue B. Notice the Parent link is correctly pointing to Issue A
# Delete issue A
# Repeat step 3 >>> we still get 1 result, issue B, even though it now has no parent

h3. Expected Results
Since the Parent issue is deleted, the search should give no result in the output.

h3. Actual Results
The JQL search is still returning the same issue in the output.
 
h3. Notes
This happens because when we delete the Parent issue the corresponding database entry is not deleted from the {{entity_property}} table.
So, searching like :
{code}SELECT * FROM entity_property e WHERE e.json_value like '%parent_id%100807%';{code}
you can still find the entry in the database even when issue id 100807 has been deleted.
fields.summary: Searching for "Parent Link is EMPTY" gives inaccurate results

Hi Team,

While i am crearting portfolio i am getting "Team management not available exception". can you please guide me how to resolve this issue
fields.summary: Teammanagement not available exception

fields.description:
Currently in Jira Software/Core there is the ability to conduct bulk changes to issues while also disabling the (email) notifications to those issues.

I would like Jira Portfolio to have this functionality also, as our teams can commit many hundreds of changes in their plans and spamming assignees email accounts is not always desired.
fields.summary: Ability to disable Jira notifications when committing plan changes
Show unviewable source's ID in "no permission to access source" message

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Adding a radio Button Custom Field to portfolio trigger an error of *TypeError: Cannot read property 'hasOriginal' of undefined*

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create plan 
# create custom field as a type "Radio Buttons" and add it to your Field scheme used by the plan
# Add the radio button field to the plan as covered in: [Configuring custom fields | https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiraportfolioserver/configuring-custom-fields-935577874.html] 
# Navigate to the plan

h3. Expected Results
No errors

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the UI:
{quote}
Please try refreshing the page. If the issue continues, please copy and paste the information in the Details button below and send to your Jira Administrator or Atlassian Support.
{quote}
Show details displays:
{code}
Cannot read property 'hasOriginal' of undefined

TypeError: Cannot read property 'hasOriginal' of undefined
{code}
!Screen Shot 2018-06-22 at 2.25.19 PM.png|thumbnail!
 
Also all issues fail to render in the plan

h3. Notes
There is no error displayed in the logs when this occurs

h3.Workaround
Remove any Custom fields of type *Radio Buttons* from the Plans Custom Fields List
fields.summary: Adding a Custom Field of type radio button causes error in portfolio

fields.description:
Currently, a Portfolio user can effectively add any Jira user as a Team member, without any sanity checks.

If the Portfolio user does not specify skills on issues and members, then the scheduler may produce nonsensical assignments.

It would be useful, if Portfolio could display a warning when the user adds a member that may be unassignable.
fields.summary: Display warning when adding unassignable users to team.

fields.description:
h2. Summary

It is not possible to see the full name of the plan's issue sources (when configuring them) if the name is larger than 36 characters.  The issue applies to all type of issue sources such as projects, boards and filters.

The Portfolio plugin does not display the full name of the issue source when:
* The issue source is already chosen as one (see screen-shot below)
* The issue source is part of the list of possible choices in the drop down list (see screen-shot below)

 !JPOSERVER_2363_IssueSources.png|thumbnail! 

h2. Environment

* JIRA Portfolio (all versions)


h2. Steps to Reproduce

# Create a board or more than one with a long name such as "Noi Team WorldCup (FIFA) ScrumBoardNumber1"
# Create a JIRA Portfolio plan
# Add issue sources to the plan while adding them notice it is not possible to see the full name of the issue source.

h2. Expected Results

The complete name of each issue source should be shown.

h2. Actual Results

The screen-shot below summarizes the actual results.  If the issue source has a very long name then it cannot be seen properly and hence it is difficult to determine which project, board or filter it is.

 !JPOSERVER_2363_IssueSources.png|thumbnail!

h2.Workaround

If possible change the name of the issue source to a shorter name, when having multiple similar names change the first part of the name to identify each one of them.


\\
fields.summary: Issue Sources' names larger than 36 characters are not fully shown when configuring issue sources

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Once a project has been archived in Jira, it can still be added as an issue source to Portfolio. There are no behavioural defects associated with this (i.e it won't cause any problems in the plan, or load any archived issues or releases), but it can be misleading.
h3. Environment

A Jira platform version that supports archiving (>= 7.10).
h3. Steps to reproduce
 # Create a Portfolio plan with two project issue sources;
 # Archive one of the projects;
 # Go to the Issue Source configuration screen for the plan.

h3. Expected results

The archived project issue source is no longer visible, and is not available as an option when adding a new issue source.
h3. Actual results

The archived project is still visible in the add issue source dropdown.
h3. Notes

No archived issues are actually loaded in the plan, and archived projects cannot be edited (e.g. by creating new releases), so functionality of the plan or the instance should not be affected.
h3. Workaround

Manually remove the issue source of the archived project.
fields.summary: Archived projects are visible on issue source configuration screen

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Troubleshooting of the Portfolio plan could be sometimes hard and require a lot of details. 
Currently it requires screen-share with end-user to fully troubleshoot it. 

h3. Suggested Solution
Improve supportability:
* add feature to export data from the portfolio page into JSON file.
* Later it can be loaded into Portfolio plan viewer. 

h3. Workaround 
Export HAR file and share with Atlassian Support
fields.summary: Improve supportability: add feature to export data from portfolio plan page

fields.description: Whenever you make a parent-level team member assignment for a parent, the configured people are only displayed on the children. It would be great if the original parent configuration would still be brought on the parent itself.
fields.summary: Display parent team members configured

fields.description:
Whenever you've got a parent and a child on a plan and change the parent issue team / team members, the change affects all children instantly. 

The suggestion is to add a confirmation box letting the customer know that the change will affect every single children.
fields.summary: Prompt team changes on parent that will affect children
Bug: Target Start and Target End fields store incorrect values in CEST within jira create rest calls
Parent Link suggest Rest Service should be able to handle issueTypeId or translated issueTypeName

fields.description:
The warning message on [https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiraportfolio/portfolio-for-jira-2-13-release-notes-946603491.html] suggested all of the 2.13 release has been cancelled but it's only 2.13.0 has been cancelled.  

Is it possible to change the wordings in the warning area from *Portfolio for Jira 2.13* to *Portfolio for Jira 2.13.0*?
fields.summary: Cancellation of 2.13.0

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, there are no versions of Portfolio that are listed as compatible with Jira Software 7.10.0 or 7.10.1.   See the marketplace listing for this plugin in https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1212136/portfolio-for-jira/version-history

h3. Suggested Solution
Ship a compatible version of this plugin for Jira Software 7.10.x.

h3. Why this is important
Without a version listed as compatible for 7.10.0 and 7.10.1, the "Find new add-ons" in Jira's UPM won't be able to install Portfolio to these versions of Jira.
fields.summary: Release a Portfolio version that is compatible with Jira 7.10.x

fields.description:
The Portfolio API does not allow creation of person entities corresponding to existing Jira users. However, the persons are not guaranteed to exist for all Jira users. Please provide a way to create persons via the API.

It could be opening the gate on {{PersonAPI}}, but it could also ensure the person entity exists when creating a new resource.

There is a possible workaround with getting {{PersonService}} via {{ComponentAccessor}} and calling {{insertJiraUserIds}} on it, but it's pretty dirty as it's not part of the public API.
fields.summary: Expose a way to create Portfolio "persons" in Java API

fields.description: Even though the API docs include {{PlanAPI}}, the service is not exported by Portfolio. Please export it as OSGI service.
fields.summary: Export PlanAPI as OSGI service

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
[Scheduling unestimated items|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiraportfolioserver/scheduling-unestimated-items-943544098.html] has the following statement for scheduling unestimated items
{quote}
Light blue work items are unestimated, but are scheduled because these have either a sprint, a release, or targets dates assigned to them
{quote}

However, current *Scheduling factors* only cover Scheduling estimated where users will be prompt of the following when a Epic/Story is not scheduled. 
!scheduling_estimate.png|thumbnail!

h3. Suggested Solution
To include scheduling unestimated items in *Scheduling factors* as well.

h3. Why this is important
Users would like to clearly understand the full functionalities of Portfolio for Jira. There are options in getting stories or epics to be scheduled and there is possibility of having it there without the need to estimate them.
fields.summary: Scheduling factors to consider Scheduling unestimated items

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
[Scheduling unestimated items|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiraportfolioserver/scheduling-unestimated-items-943544098.html] is generalized for scheduling unestimated items with the following:
{quote}
Light blue work items are unestimated, but are scheduled because these have either a sprint, a release, or targets dates assigned to them
{quote}

It is unclear when certain values are not seen in Portfolio Plan due to being in different Issue sources. It is important to understand the behavior of what Issue Sources will do to refer back to the above statement.

h3. Suggested Solution
Clarify the following about Issue sources
* Board source - will pull Sprint data only when the Scrum Board containing the sprint is assigned to a Team in Plan
* Project/JQL source - will not pull any Sprint data

h3. Why this is important
There are cases where a user is expecting the Story or Epic to be scheduled unestimated after assigning to a Sprint in Jira *but* it is not reflected in Portfolio Plan.
fields.summary: Scheduling behavior on Unestimated items for different Issue Sources are unclear

fields.description:
Assuming the Portfolio hierarchy is as follows:

    Initiative

        |_ Strategy

            |_ Epic

                |_ Story / Bug

Currently  it is not possible to link a Bug to a Strategy or an Epic to an initiative. You need to create the full hierarchy in order to attach an item under its initiative.

This feature request is to allow this:

So if a bug is under a Strategy but does not have an Epic, it should appear in a section "Issues without parent Epic" under the Strategy.
fields.summary: Link issue to "grand-parent" issue

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

When we try to link two issues using the Parent link field, it fills the Parent link drop down field with 100 issues (there is a hard coded limit for displaying 100 issues). If the user needs to look for another issue, he needs to type the exact issue key as there is no search being triggered.

 

h3. Suggested Solution

Please trigger a search on "Parent Link" field as the user types in the issue key.
fields.summary: As a user I would like the "Parent link" field to trigger search as I type the issue key

The Parent Link field (Portfolio for Jira) currently allows users to select issues that are closed. I cannot imagine a use case where this would make sense.

As far as I know the Epic Link field doesn't allow closed Epics to be selected. And I suggest to make the Parent Link field behave in that way as well.

h3. Summary
According to this documentation : https://docs.atlassian.com/portfolio-for-jira-server/REST/2.13.0/jpo/, the REST api call for deleting a Program is 
{code}DELETE /program/{id}{code}
however it is not working as expected.



h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a Program 
# Try to delete it using Portfolio API : {code}[Base url]/rest/jpo-api/1.0/program/{id}{code}

h3. Expected Results
The program is deleted and you get a response code 200

h3. Actual Results
 The program is not deleted and you get a response code 400


h3.Workaround
The following call is working fine :
{code}[Base url]/rest/jpo/1.0/programs/{id}{code}
fields.summary: JIRA REST api for DELETE Program is not working

Unavailable resource shouldn't be assigned any issue.

 

Actual:

It gets issue assigned.

h3. Notes
It appears there are several older versions of Jira that are end of life, such as 6.3.x up through 7.1.x that are still listed as compatible for many portfolio versions per [Portfolio for Jira - Version history|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1212136/portfolio-for-jira/version-history].   So this leads customers to have an expectation that their older version of Jira can still use the very latest version of Portfolio, when that does not currently seem to be the case.

h3.Workaround
I found other versions of Portfolio do not seem to have this problem.  You could work around this problem by following these steps:
# Uninstall Portfolio from the UPM (Add-ons -> Manage Add-ons).  Be sure to remove all 3 Portfolio addons listed there
# Download another version such as 2.2.6 from https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1212136/portfolio-for-jira/version-history 
# save this file to your local machine
# In Jira on the manage add-ons page, there is a link to 'Upload add-ons', click this
# select the downloaded package to install this older version of portfolio that works with your version of Jira.

fields.description:
I want to use boards as data sources for convenience and to get the velocity info for the associated teams.  However, since the board filters show sub-tasks, once I add 7-8 boards to the plan, it gets very slow and can go over the 5000 issue limit.  Sub-tasks aren't relevant for planning at the portfolio level.  Some suggestions:
 # Just give an option to exclude sub-tasks, OR
 # Make a way to add a JQL filter to the data sources to exclude certain things that would otherwise be included (sub-tasks, very old issues, etc.).

I can't find a workaround for this.  If I just based the plan off JQL, then the teams' correct velocity isn't shown.
fields.summary: Ability to exclude sub-tasks from board data sources

fields.description:
Hello Amazing Portfolio Project Team!! We were just sitting in a team meeting here at our company and we came up with a great idea. We just had to share it with you. 

Our organization thrives on Kanban boards but the Roadmaps created by Portfolio are amazing for seeing the big picture too. But as we all know the big picture sometimes changes. This is where our big idea comes in. We thought it would be really "cool" and useful if there was a way to capture snapshots of the Roadmap over time throughout the year so a team could look back and see how the Roadmap has changed. This would also be useful for sharing with our business owners so they can see how their decisions, over time, can have an impact on other projects and people resources. Now, go create a "Snapshot" feature and be even more amazing!!

Regards,

The Enterprise Information Technology Team
at Montana Dakota Utilities.
fields.summary: Create "SnapShot" functionality to capture snapshots of the Roadmap throughout the year.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

The Portfolio "Team" field is currently locked. This makes it impossible to make this field required in field configurations. 

An important use case is when you have multiple teams using the same project. To be able to separate the different Team's board filters you would want to use the Team field. To make this work you need to make sure field is always filled in to avoid new issues from disappearing from the boards. 

When creating an issue and committing this to Jira, you must make a field required in the field configurations. To use a scripted validator will not work in this case, as this will cause an error.
h3. Suggested solution

Unlock field to make it possible to use in field configurations.
fields.summary: Add possibilty to make Team field required in field configuration

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Committing changes in Portfolio back to Jira is slow on large instances (~ millions of issues).

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a Jira instance (>1 million issues);
# Create a Portfolio plan (any size);
# Create a long sequence of uncommitted changes in Portfolio (>25 operations);
# Commit all changes back to Jira.

h3. Expected Results
2-3 individual commit operations are processed per second.

h3. Actual Results.
Each individual commit operation takes >1 second.

h3. Workaround
Commit changes in smaller batches to prevent long running operations.
fields.summary: Committing is slow on large instances

- [Managing your team's availability | https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiraportfolioserver/managing-your-team-s-availability-715262845.html]

It would be highly useful to be able to manage the full team availability rather than just the individual members within the team, 

EXE use case being:
* a group of contractors all under the same team being added in with a scheduled hire date and scheduled end date on the contract.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add an option to Portfolio Team to set the full teams availability rather than just the individual users within the team
fields.summary: Manage Team Availability

fields.description:
h3. From customer feedback it would seem that it is not clear that *unestimated* issues that block other issues will not have an impact on the scheduling of the blocked issues. There appears to be an expectation that the target end date of an unestimated issue will impact the scheduled start date of blocked issues when this is not the case. Another issue (https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-2323) has been raised to make some changes to the scheduling algorithm, but it might be prudent to update the existing documentation in the meantime to clarify the situation.

These the suggested pages to consider improving (although there may be others):
 * [https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiraportfoliocloud/scheduling-unestimated-items-based-on-default-estimates-844236853.html]
 * [https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiraportfoliocloud/add-target-start-and-target-end-dates-868977060.html]

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a project with issues A and B
 # Make issue B blocked by issue A
 # Create a plan for that project
 # Give an estimate to issue B
 # Give target start and end dates to issue A
 # Click "calculate" to schedule the issues

h3. Expected Results

It could reasonably be expected that issue B will not have a calculated start date that is before the target end date of A (because it is a known date).
h3. Actual Results

B will start as the same time as A (because A is not considered in scheduling because it has no estimate).
h3. Workaround

Give an estimate to issue A.
fields.summary: Improve documentation around scheduling behaviour of unestimated blocking issues

fields.description:
h3. If issue B is blocked by issue A but issue A has no estimate but does have a target end date then the scheduled start date for issue B should not be before that target end date. Although this is working as intended it is potentially confusing (unestimated issues are not considered when scheduling) there are improvements that we could potentially make.
h3. Environment

(Optional - If Applicable)
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a project with issues A and B
 # Make issue B blocked by issue A
 # Create a plan for that project
 # Give an estimate to issue B
 # Give target start and end dates to issue A
 # Click "calculate" to schedule the issues

h3. Expected Results

It could reasonably be expected that issue B will not have a calculated start date that is before the target end date of A (because it is a known date).
h3. Actual Results

B will start as the same time as A (because A is not considered in scheduling because it has no estimate).
h3. Workaround

Give an estimate to issue A.
fields.summary: Improve scheduling of issues blocked by unestimated dependants

fields.description:
h3. With the release of Portfolio for Jira API, we would like to start capturing your requests for future improvements and functionalities.

_Please leave comments on what you want us to build and why it is important for you._

*Link to current API docs:*

[https://docs.atlassian.com/portfolio-for-jira-server/REST/2.12.0/?_ga=2.235571713.1427061789.1525044874-1394391608.1517357012]

fields.description:
Per the Documentation:
- [Mapping issue assignees to team members | https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiraportfolioserver/map-an-issue-assignee-to-a-team-member-868977966.html]

The noted Items required for the Members field to import the assignee are:
{quote}
For the Jira issue assignee to show in the team member column in Portfolio for Jira, these conditions must apply:
* There is no member set in Portfolio for Jira.
* The assignee is set on the issue in Jira.
* The assignee is part of a team in your plan.
* If you've made a manual team assignment, make sure the assignee is part of that team.
* To see the assignee that is being pulled from Jira, you have to calculate your plan.
* The issue assignee import level must be set to a hierarchy level. See [Configuring initiatives and other hierarchy levels|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiraportfolioserver/configuring-initiatives-and-other-hierarchy-levels-802170489.html].
{quote}

But the requirements for calculation to associate this user is not clearly defined:
{quote}
To see the assignee that is being pulled from Jira, you have to calculate your plan.
{quote} 

This pulls in elements from some additional documentation [Scheduling and timeline|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiraportfolioserver/scheduling-and-timeline-802170550.html], [Scheduling behavior|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiraportfolioserver/scheduling-behavior-802170552.html] & [Scheduling unestimated items|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiraportfolioserver/scheduling-unestimated-items-943544098.html] to piece this behavior togather BUT does not clearly define that this also requires an estimate or a manual Sprint association for the assignee to populate in the member column with the following variables to make this true:

If *Unestimated item scheduling* is set to:
* *Base on default estimates* & a value is set for the default values (Sprint, Epic, Initiative...)
** Assignee will be populated per the user assigned to the issue in jira as a default estimate is added to un-estimated issues to allow the calculation to occur
* *Base on target dates*
** Requires Either an Estimate or Manual Sprint association
* *Custom*
** Requires Either an Estimate or Manual Sprint association
* *Off*
** Requires an Estimate
fields.summary: Provide clarification on Calculation requirements for Assignee import level

fields.description:

h3. If the same Epic exists in multiple plans and those plans have issue sources that result in the epic being scheduled at different times or to take different lengths (because of excluded child issues) and those plans are shown included in a program. Then the first plan in the program will display the epic with a tooltip indicating the start and end dates as being the maximum range of implementation time across all the plans.

The the tooltip for the epic should should start and end dates that match it's position on the timeline
h3. Actual Results

The first plan in the program shows the epic as having start and end dates that span the full program.

When using a board filter using the Portfolio team field exe:

team = 1 Order by Rank ASC
{code}

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When a plan is created that is based on a JQL query that does not contain any project ids and yields a very large number of issues it is possible to cause an out-of-memory exception. 

This is because the {{getProjectIdsViaExhaustiveSearch}} function attempts to determine the project IDs by running the JQL query and then iterating over the results to find the set of projects in the plan. However, the search is performed without any limit on the number of results and this means that if there are a lot of results then memory can be exhausted during the processing.

h3. Environment
* Large instance with > 1M issues 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# generate 1M issues
# create Portfolio Plan with empty board filter
# load this board repeatedly

h3. Expected Results
* there should be a limit of issues can be loaded in a single board
* there should be a validation check for creating board with empty filter 


h3. Actual Results
Jira consumes large heap and eventually OOME
 
h3. Notes
Suggested resolution is to have to page over all the results (with the page size being that of the issue limit) to ensure that issues are processed in manageable chunks.

h3.Workaround

Retrieve the empty JQL plans using the following SQL query
{code:borderStyle=dashed}
select "p"."TITLE", "is"."SOURCE_TYPE", "is"."SOURCE_VALUE","rv"."SAVED_FILTER_ID", sr.reqcontent 
from "AO_D9132D_ISSUE_SOURCE" "is" full 
join "AO_60DB71_RAPIDVIEW" "rv" on cast("is"."SOURCE_VALUE" as int) = "rv"."ID" 
join searchrequest sr on (sr.id = "rv"."SAVED_FILTER_ID" or sr.id = cast("is"."SOURCE_VALUE" as int))
join "AO_D9132D_PLAN" "p" on "p"."ID" = "is"."PLAN_ID"
where sr.reqcontent = '' OR sr.reqcontent IS NULL;
{code}

Once identified, reach out to the respective user to update the JQL query.
fields.summary: Filters yielding large issue result set can cause out-of-memory exception

fields.description:
h5. Problem Definition
Following this hierarchy structure
* Feature
* Epic
* Story
* Sub-task

At the moment, In plan's scope view, the plan will only show direct parent link, for example, showing Epic for Story or showing Feature for Epic. It is currently not possible to show the parent link of it's parent. For example, showing Feature for Story.

h5. Suggested Solution

fields.summary: The option to show the parent link of one's parent (as column in scope view)

fields.description:
h2. Summary

The issue's history is not updated when assigning a team (Teams field) to it in the JIRA Portfolio plan scope view.  The same happens when changing the Teams fields value. 
Please note that updating the Teams field from the JIRA issue view will update the issue's history.  The problem only happens when adding a value to the Teams field from the JIRA Portfolio Plan Scope view.



h2. Environment

* JIRA Portfolio 2.12.1


h2. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a JIRA Portfolio plan with at least a team and some issues
# Add the Teams field in the JIRA Portfolio Scope view
# Assign a team to an issue
# Commit changes
# Goto the JIRA issue view and find the issue
# Check that the Teams field is shown for that issue however the issue's history is not updated


h2. Expected Results

The issue's history should be updated when a change is applied to the Teams field in the JIRA Portfolio Plan Scope view.


h2. Actual Results

The issue's history is not updated when a change is applied to the Teams field in the JIRA Portfolio Plan Scope view.
 

h2.Workaround

The only way to get the issue's history is to update the Teams field from the JIRA issue view (editing the issue and assigning a value to the Teams field).

h2. Additional Information (Screenshots)

h3. Assigning a value to the Teams field
 !JPO_view_1.png|thumbnail! 

h3. JIRA Issue view
The issue has the Teams field with the value assigned in JIRA Portfolio however there is not track of the change in the history.
 !Issue_view_2.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Editing the field
Now we update the value from the JIRA Portfolio Scope view and we commit the changes.
 !JPO_view_3.png|thumbnail!

 !JPO_view_4.png|thumbnail! 

h3. JIRA Issue view
After updating the value from the JIRA Portfolio Scope view the issue's history is not updated either.
 !Issue_view_5.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: The issue's history is not updated when assigning a team (Teams field) to it in the JIRA Portfolio plan or when changing the Teams fields value.

fields.description:
h3. Steps to reproduce:
 # In a Portfolio plan, set the 'Unestimated item scheduling' option to 'Base on target dates'
 # Create a release with dynamic start and/or end date
 # Assign an issue with no estimate, sprint assignment or target dates to that release
 # Calculate the plan

h3. Expected outcome:

The 'Scheduling Factors' section in the issue details section should give a warning that the issue has no estimate
h3. Actual outcome:

The 'Scheduling Factors' section only has a message about recalculating the plan.
fields.summary: 'Scheduling factors' section shows incorrect message when unscheduled item is assigned to a release

fields.description:
Some customized agile solutions, i.e: scaled agile frameworks( SAFe, DaD and LeSS, etc..) are using terminology which is not fully supported with the Atlassian product line.

Example:
 * You may want to structure your project hierarchy as  Epic > Feature > story but in Jira the structure is fixed for Epic > Story
fields.summary: Support terminology of scaled agile frameworks

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Jira Portfolio issues may have a *Target start* and *Target end* date custom field. When querying against these custom fields in the Issue Navigator using either Basic or Advanced search using JQL, these fields do not behave as expected when compared to Jira's own *Date Picker* and *Date Time Picker* custom fields.

Specifically, issues behave as though their *Target start* and *Target end* values are a day behind their actual value. Put it another way, issues are only returned in the Issue Navigator if queries which query against these two date fields successfully include a date range for the day *prior* to the actual value.

h3. Environment

* JIRA 7.4.2+
* JIRA Portfolio 2.12.1

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Identify an issue which has either *Target start* or *Target end* set. For the sake of example, let's say that an issue has a *Target start* of 2018/03/15.
# In the issue navigator, attempt to search for this issue using any of the following JQL which we would expect would return the issue:
* "Target start" >= '2018/03/15'
* "Target start" = '2018/03/15'
* "Target start" > '2018/03/14'

h3. Expected Results

The issue in question would be returned in the results.

h3. Actual Results

The issue is not returned in the results. The issue will only return for any of the following queries that would return as though the *Target start* was actually 2018/03/14.
* "Target start" >= '2018/03/14'
* "Target start" = '2018/03/14'
* "Target start" <= '2018/03/14'

h3. Workaround

Because the behavior is consistent in that the queries act as though the date were a day behind, JQL queries may safely be adjusted backwards a day to compensate.
fields.summary: Target Start and Target End custom fields behave as though they were a day behind when searching in Issue Navigator

fields.description: Items that have no estimate are not shown in the Schedule view as they cannot be scheduled, however, we should warn about that in some way - possibly within the "Scheduling factors" section.
fields.summary: Warn about items in scope that don't have an estimate set

fields.description:
In some cases when filtering a plan, child issues of the issues we filter for may not be present. This can cause confusing behaviour (e.g. issues no longer showing in the schedule) when the issues don't have estimates but their child issues do.

It would be good to have an option to include all relevant child issues when filtering a plan, so that the scheduling of items doesn't change when the plan is filtered for those items.
fields.summary: Add option to include child issues when filtering plan

fields.description:
h3. Summary
An Issue is added to a Release when calculated in the Plan Scope when an Issue also has fixversion set to None, this is occuring when the issue is also associated to a Sprint that has a end date less than the release date and the Team is set to Kanban


h3. Steps to Reproduce
* In a project Create a Release with a date value in the future.
* Create a Scrum Board for that project
* Create a Sprint and set the End Date so that it is Less than the Release Date Created in step 1
* On issues make sure FixVersion is set to NONE
* Create a Plan using the following for the issue source:
** project import level 
** Select all releases
** Team Set to Kanban
* calculate 

h3. Expected Results
Fix Version is empty or set to LATER

h3. Actual Results
The Release is populated with the one created where *"Release Date > Sprint End date"*
 
h3. Notes
Portfolio simulates future sprint when using Project import level, those sprints are not actually created.   Conflict point seems to be the simulated Sprints created when using Project import level causing the Actual Sprint to be masked so the issue has a set end date within the range of the the Release so Portfolio failing over to a release in that window as Sprint is missing

h3.Workaround
Set Team to Scrum
fields.summary: Issues Added to Release when Fix version is None

fields.description: The new JQL functions for Portfolio are great and I can see hiw these will be very useful on dashboard gadgets. It would be very helpful to be able to sort by hierarchy so that issue types are located together in the search results.
fields.summary: Create a means to sort by Portfolio hierarchy in JQL

fields.description: Currently the utilization of a team in Portfolio can reach 100%. In reality in many cases the utilization will max out at say 80% due to meetings etcetera. Currently it is not possible to define such a limit
fields.summary: Add the possibility to define a maximum utilisation for a team

fields.description:
h3. h3. The issue

Currently, to have the real work done reflected in Portfolio, we have to use Story Points to measure our work to complete items. But our developer are more comfortable to estimate the work to do in hours or days.
h3. h3. The resolution

Like having a velocity of story points for the teams in Portfolio, we would like to have a velocity for original time estimates done in the past sprints, like the Velocity Chart in the reporting tool of JIRA, as well as a forecast of original time estimates for the next sprints.

With it, we are more able to use the portfolio planning features as having to use story points to estimate work.
fields.summary: Team velocity should work with Original Time Estimates too, like the Velocity Chart Report

fields.description:
Portfolio for Jira allows teams to be tracked by a team name. The page where you can see the team names can not be reordered. This has an effect on the Team Field used elsewhere in Jira such that the pull down list showing all the team names is in the order of when the names were entered.

This request is to allow for the pull down list of the Team Field to be sorted alphabetically. A follow on request would be to allow for any sort order.

Additional information from the Atlassian Jira team member:
 * Team names *are not* alphabetized in the Team field dropdown in Jira Software and are organized based on the order in which they were added to the plan.
 * Team names *are not* alphabetized in the Manage Shared Teams page in Portfolio for Jira and are organized based on the order in which they were added.
 * Team names *are* alphabetized in a Portfolio for Jira plan. However, uppercase and lowercase letters are not treated the same; capitalized team names are put first. For example, 'Ze team' is put before 'a team'.
fields.summary: Ability to reorder Team list

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Changes to view filters and view settings in Jira Portfolio's backlog do not save and need to be reconfigured each time you re-visit the backlog after logging out (or opening in another browser, browser cache flushed, etc). 
h3. Suggested solution

Add the ability to save view filters and settings on a per user basis so that program managers, teams and stakeholders can configure their view as desired, and quickly load the same view each time they visit the Portfolio backlog. 
h4. Work Around

None. Filters and settings must be reconfigured each time.
fields.summary: Add ability to save filtered views and view settings

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

In Portfolio, certain configurations allow Users and Groups to be added. Examples of such configurations:
* Administration >> Add-ons >> Portfolio permissions
!image-2018-03-21-18-56-46-990.png|thumbnail! 
* Portfolio Plan/Program Administration >> Permissions
!image-2018-03-21-18-56-36-176.png|thumbnail! 

Users and Groups that are too long will be truncated with ellipses (*...*), making it impossible to differentiate between them if there are multiple names that are similar or begin with the same characters. This makes it difficult to select the Users/Groups that are desired.

h3. Suggested Solution

Implement a mechanism that allows users to view more characters. This could include:
* Allowing the dropdown list to be resized, rendering more or less characters as fits on screen.
* Instead of truncating, allow for side scrolling in the window

h3. Why this is important
 
Users cannot properly differentiate which User/Group they're looking for when the names are too long. They will have to guess, or must know the name of the group exactly.
fields.summary: User/Group selectors in Portfolio truncate long names

fields.description:
Based on my testing of this option in Portfolio for Jira with customers, I think that the sub-task Option Issue Import Level should be removed and documentation improved.

In summary here is the issue and the recommendation:

Portfolio for Jira has an option called _Issue Import Level_ for building the schedule. There are a number of possible options and this feedback is related specifically to the Sub-Task option. 

In summary: 
 When you set the option for *Issue Assignee Import Level to Story*, Portfolio for Jira correctly handles this Use case:
 1) Story with no sub-tasks - it imports the actual Jira assignee into Portfolio
 2) Story with Sub-tasks - it imports the assignee on the Sub-tasks

When you set the option for *Issue Assignee Import Level to Sub-Tasks*, Portfolio for Jira seems to get confused:
 1) Story with no sub-tasks - it FAILS to import the actual Jira assignee into Portfolio
 2) Story with Sub-tasks - it imports the assignee on the Sub-tasks

Based on this logic, I think that the Sub-Task option should be removed since it provides no value and handles a very limited USE case that is not representative of what happens in the real world. The Sub-Task option is *assuming that if a Team uses Sub-Task it will have Sub-Tasks for EVERY story*. This is a very Corner Case which I think is Extremely rare based on the realities of what teams do on a daily basis. I have yet to find a team that uses Sub-Tasks so diligently that they will create Sub-Tasks for every Story.

Therefore, why have an option that brings no real value to the product? I propose that this Option be removed. It only causes confusion to your end-users. If not you should at least document how this option works and the assumptions that the Portfolio makes around this option.

One final comment on the Documentation you have at this link:

[https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiraportfolioserver/mapping-issue-assignees-to-team-members-868977966.html]

It is great to talk about EPIC's and Stories but you don't cover the next level down which is where the problem is. The customers I work with set this value to Story and Portfolio is correctly handling even the next level down into Sub-Tasks. There is nothing in your documentation about what to expect when a customer uses a mix of issue Hierarchies in the SAME Jira project:

1) EPIC-Stories,

2) EPIC-Stories-Sub-Tasks,

3) Stories-Sub-Tasks

which is what happens in the industry all the time. This is actually working correctly now when you use the Story and EPIC Issue Assignee Import level settings and I recommend documenting it.
fields.summary: Remove the Sub-Task Issue Import Level since it causes confusion and little value

fields.description:
h4. Steps to reproduce:
 # Create a plan from a board
 # Add a sprint to the board
 # Add a new team to the plan, and have that team associated with the same board
 # Create a story with a subtask. Give estimates to both
 # Assign the story to the new team, and the new sprint
 # Calculate the plan

h4. Expected outcome:

The story should be scheduled
h4. Actual outcome:

The story cannot be scheduled and shows a scheduling error:

'*This issue can't be scheduled because this issue and its sub-tasks are assigned to different teams*'.
fields.summary: Subtasks are set to the wrong team when multiple teams share the same sprint

fields.description:
Currently it's only possible to manually assign, either in Portfolio or Jira, a story-level issue to a single sprint while stages could be done in different sprints.

When letting Portfolio calculate the issues this work "within Portfolio" but as the manual assignment is not possible, this can't be reflected in Jira / Boards.

It is not viable to use sub-tasks to split the work as sub-tasks can't be assigned to a different sprint that its parent.

Workaround is to either create multiple stories for each stage and use issue links to represent the relation, or use a level of hierarchy above for the main task and to cut it down per stage at the story level.
fields.summary: Allow to associate different stages with different sprints

fields.description:
By default (all un-checked) the status filter does not seem to always retrieve "Done" issues that are matching the completion date filter.

Filtering for all statuses (all status checked) retrieves done issue currently but does not seem to always respect the completion date filter.
fields.summary: Status filtering is not respected

fields.description:
A program has been created with multiple plans. The release dates for epics are projected based on their contents, and no Fix Versions are assigned at the epic or above levels in Jira.
 # Open Portfolio to view the program at the Epic level
 # Filter for any of the plans with a date range of Full
 # All releases for the plan are displayed
 # Change the date range using dates that would include the release(s) that were shown in the Full date range view

Expected Results: The same releases that were displayed at the Full date range should be displayed

Actual Results: No data is displayed

The cause of this is probably due to the epics not having assigned Fix Versions in Jira, but this is not intuitive to end users.
fields.summary: No data on programs when date range is selected

fields.description:
Ability to view Portfolio plans in JIRA mobile app. With Scrum Masters, Product Owners, Project Managers spending more time in meetings and not sitting at a desk, they need the ability to use Portfolio in the JIRA Server Mobile app. Without this ability, they will have to switch between the JIRA Server Mobile app and a web browser.
Please create a seamless environment for the JIRA Server Mobile app and the Portfolio for JIRA Server.
fields.summary: Compatibility with Mobile app for JIRA server

fields.description:
Hi all, 

is there a way to filter issue shown in parent link list?

For example, if I want to create a third level element from Jira and not form portfolio, can I add a field to select the first level parent issue and than view the parent link filtered by the option  choosen on the previous field? 

 

Thank you
fields.summary: Filter issue in parent link

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, if a Portfolio plan is configured with the following Hierarchy:

{code}
Initiative -> Epic -> Story level issue types
{code}

# The initiative issue has sub-task
# Select *Initiative* level in Plan

Sub-task of the Initiative will not be shown in the plan. 


h3. Suggested Solution

Allow sub-task of the Initiative & Epic to be shown in the Plan (Scope view)


h3. Workaround 

None
fields.summary: Display Subtask in Scope view

fields.description:
Currently, Portfolio defaults to UTC when the user does not specify a Plan Timezone, see 
{code:java}
com.atlassian.rm.jpo.core.scheduling.load.DefaultPlanDataLoader#getPlanTimeZone
{code}

This causes some strange artefacts surrounding the sprint start times.
Example: if a sprint starts on 6 March at 10:00am (in Sydney), then Portfolio translates that to a sprint start date of 5 March.

This can be confusing, as users would expect Portfolio's out-of-box configuration to match the Jira defaults.
fields.summary: Use system default timezone for plans

fields.summary: Some Portfolio custom fields missing from the lucene index after re-indexing

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Filtering by Issue summary does not show issue in scheduler for Hierarchies above stories

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Make sure you have multiple hierarchies setup with issues in them. 
# In the portfolio plan, switch the scheduler to Story Hierarchy
# You will see all the stories listed on the scope table, and this is also reflected on the scheduler. 
# Search for a story by its summary. Eg: "Big" for a story by the name of "Big Story"
# This show narrow down the issues in the scope table and the scheduler to issues with "Big" in its summary
# Now switch to Epic Hierarchy level
# Search for an issue by its summary 

h3. Expected Results

Should further filter to show issues with that string for both the scope table and scheduler. 

h3. Actual Results

Only shows the results in the scope table. The scheduler returns empty.
fields.summary: Filtering by summary does not show issue in scheduler for Hierarchies above stories

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

The 'Completion Date' filter is hidden underneath the *More* drop-down. It's not obvious when viewing scope that there is a filter being applied. Since it defaults to issues completed in the last 30 days, it appears that completed items are missing from scope when in fact, they are just being hidden. 

h3. Suggested Solution

Display  'Completion Date' filter by default, next to 'Teams'. There is also white space next to the More drop-down that can be utilized.  See: https://cl.ly/1H3c0n2H201E

h3. Why this is important

Customers believe that data is missing from their plan.
fields.summary: Display 'Completion Date' filter by default on Scope

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

The 'Completion Date' filter on a plan currently defaults to 'Completed Issues from the last 30 days' in the Scope view.  This causes confusion for users who are viewing the Scope as it appears that completed items are missing from the plan. It's not obvious that the filter is being applied to the plan without clicking on the *More* drop-down. It's not possible for an administrator to change this default behavior. 

h3. Suggested Solution

Allow the default setting to be configurable under Configure > Scheduling. 

h3. Why this is important
 
Current behavior causes confusion and administrators can't head it off by changing the default.
fields.summary: Configurable default value for 'Completion Date' filter on plan Scope view

fields.description:
h5. Problem
When creating a plan on step 5, "Confirm what's in scope", it does not list all existing Epics. Only Epics with linked issues are displayed. Epics without linked tickets do not appear.

h5. Steps to Reproduce
* Create Agile board with multiple Epics
* Ensure at least 1 Epic does not have linked issues
* Use this Board to create a plan

Video of this behaviour attached.
 !scope.mov|thumbnail!

h5. Expected Behaviour
Epics that will appear in the plan will also appear during "Confirm what's in scope"
fields.summary: When Creating Plan, Scope is Missing Epics

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, in order for any changes from the plan to be reflected in Portfolio graph, user will have to re-calculate the plan so Portfolio can re-calculate the change and update what's shown in the graph.

Some users would like Portfolio to automatically display the changes in the graph (in real time) when changes are done in the plan.


h3. Suggested Solution

Allow Portfolio to render detail in graph real time when plan is edited.


h3. Workaround 

None.
fields.summary: Change detail in plan in real time when issue detail is modified
